Fig. 1 The front and top views of the α-Fe2O3 (0 0 1) supercell. (Blue: Fe; Red: O.) (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 1 Fig. 2 The possible adsorption sites of alkali metals on the α-Fe2O3 (001) surface and the corresponding optimized models (1)–(3). (Blue: Fe, Red: O, Green: K.) (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 2 Fig. 3 PDOS of (a) K, Na and O (b)Fe 3d of the Fe2O3, Na-Fe2O3 and K-Fe2O3 models. (Free K/Na: the isolated atoms of K or Na; Fe-3d/Fe2O3: the 3d orbital of Fe of the fresh Fe2O3 model; Fe-3d/K or Na-Fe2O3: the 3d orbital of Fe of the K or Na-Fe2O3 model.) Fig. 3 Fig. 4 The optimized adsorption configuration of the NH3 molecule on the Lewis acid sites of K/Na-Fe2O3 systems. (Blue: Fe, Red: O, Yellow: Na, Purple: K.) (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 4 Fig. 5 The optimized adsorption configuration of the NH3 molecule on the Brønsted acid sites of K/Na-Fe2O3 systems. (Blue: Fe, Red: O, Yellow: Na, Purple: K) (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 5 Fig. 6 PDOS of (a) N (sum of s and p orbital) (b)Fe 3d of the Fe2O3, Na-Fe2O3 and K-Fe2O3 models. (Free N: the N atom of the isolated NH3 molecule; N/Na-Fe2O3/NH3: the N atom of the NH3 molecule adsorbed in the Lewis site of the Na-Fe2O3 model; Fe-3d/Fe2O3/NH3: the 3d orbital of Fe of the fresh Fe2O3 model with NH3 adsorbed in the Lewis site; Fe-3d/ Na-Fe2O3/NH3: the 3d orbital of Fe of the Na-Fe2O3 model with NH3 adsorbed in the Lewis site.) Fig. 6 Fig. 7 PDOS of (a) FeOH (the Brønsted acid site) (b)N, Na and K of the Fe2O3, Na-Fe2O3 and K-Fe2O3 models. (Free N: the N atom of the isolated NH3 molecule; N/Na-Fe2O3/NH3: the N of the NH3 adsorbed on Brønsted acid site of the Na-Fe2O3 model; Na/Na-Fe2O3/NH3: the Na in the Na-Fe2O3 model with NH3 adsorbed on the Brønsted acid site; FeOH/Na-Fe2O3/NH3: the FeOH in the Na-Fe2O3 model with NH3 adsorbed on the Brønsted acid site.) Fig. 7 Fig. 8 The optimized adsorption structures of NOx molecules adsorbed on the Na/K-Fe2O3 models. (Blue: Fe, Red: O, Yellow: Na, Purple: K, Dark Blue: N.) (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Optimized adsorption structures of O2 adsorbed on the Na/K-Fe2O3 systems. (Blue: Fe, Red: O, Yellow: Na, Purple: K.) (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 9 Fig. 10 The potential energy diagram of the reaction of (a) NH3 dehydrogenation and (b) formation of H2O. Fig. 10 Fig. 11 Optimized structures of the reactants, products and the transition states of (a) NH3 dehydrogenation and (b) formation of H2O in the K-Fe2O3 system. (Blue: Fe, Red: O, Purple: K, Dark Blue: N.) (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 11 Table 1 The adsorption energies (E ad/eV) of alkali metals on the α-Fe2O3 (001) surface. Table 1 Na K Ead (Fe2O3)/eV 3.34 3.72 Ead (V2O5) /eV 4.47 4.37 Table 2 The optimized geometries and adsorption energies of NH3 on the Lewis acid sites and the Brønsted acid sites of K/Na-Fe2O3 systems. (Ead: the adsorption energy of NH3; N-Fe: the distance between the N atom of the NH3 molecule and the Fe atom; N-H: the distance between the N atom and the H atom of the Brønsted acid sites.). Table 2 Lewis acid site Brønsted acid site Ead(eV) N-Fe(Å) Ead(eV) N-H(Å) Fe2O3 1.22 2.14 0.44 1.69 Na-Fe2O3 1.11 2.17 0.70 2.86 K-Fe2O3 1.15 2.16 0.63 2.98 Table 3 The optimized geometries, adsorption energies of NOx in the Fe2O3, Na-Fe2O3 and K-Fe2O3 system. (Ead-NO: the adsorption energy of NO; N-Fe/NO: the distance between the Fe atom and the N atom of the NO molecule; Ead-NO: the adsorption energy of NO.). Table 3 Ead-NO (eV) N-Fe/NO (Å) Ead-NO2 (eV) N-Fe/NO2 (Å) Fe2O3 0.541 2.16 1.18 2.13 Na-Fe2O3 0.741 2.21 2.09 2.16 K-Fe2O3 1.656 1.81 2.09 2.11 Theoretical insights into the poisoning effect of Na and K on α-Fe2O3 catalyst for selective catalytic reduction of NO with NH3 Zekang Lyu Conceptualization Methodology Writing - original draft Writing - review & editing Shengli Niu Supervision Writing - review & editing Project administration * Kuihua Han Project administration Chunmei Lu Writing - review & editing Yingjie Li Writing - review & editing School of Energy and Power Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan 250061, Shandong, China School of Energy and Power Engineering Shandong University Jinan Shandong 250061 China School of Energy and Power Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan 250061, Shandong, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The poisoning effect of potassium (K) and sodium (Na) on the α-Fe2O3 catalyst in the ammonia-selective catalytic reduction (NH3-SCR) for the NO reduction was investigated by the density functional theory calculation. The results show that, in the presence of alkali metals, the strength of the Lewis acid site on the surface is not affected, while the strength of the Brønsted acid site is significantly inhibited, which thus decreases the de-NOx performance of the α-Fe2O3 catalyst. Both K and Na enhance the NOx (NO and NO2) adsorption capacity and inhibit the O2 adsorption capacity of the α-Fe2O3 catalyst. These data indicate that NO and NH3 form competitive adsorption, and the ‘Fast-SCR’ reaction is inhibited in the alkali metal poisoned systems. In addition, the alkali metals don't affect the dehydrogenation of NH3, but inhibit the formation of H2O which is the rate determination step of NH3-SCR for α-Fe2O3 catalyst. Keywords α-Fe2O3 DFT NH3-SCR Alkali metal poisoning 1 Introduction The nitric oxides (NOx) released from the coal combustion can give rise to the photochemical smog and ozone hole [1,2]. At present, one of the most effective methods to eliminate NOx emissions is selective catalytic reduction using ammonia as the reductant (NH3-SCR), where the catalyst plays an important role. The commercial V2O5/TiO2 catalyst is effective in NH3-SCR, which is however depressed by the narrowed temperature window and the toxicity of vanadium [3,4]. Therefore, it is important to develop the efficient catalysts for NH3-SCR without toxicity. Up to now, the iron-based catalyst with the α-Fe2O3 phase has attracted extensive attentions in SCR reaction due to its great redox ability. Liu [5] prepared WOx/Fe2O3 catalyst and reported that the optimal catalyst presents good NOx conversion and N2 selectivity from 300 ℃ to 450 ℃. The MoO3 doped Fe2O3 catalyst was researched by Wang [6], and the catalyst provided high resistance of SO2/H2O poisoning and great NH3-SCR performance from 225℃ to 400 ℃. Improving the sulfur resistance and alkali metal resistance of de-NOX catalysts has always been research difficulty and hot spot [7–9]. It is well known that the alkali metals in the fly ash can deactivate the SCR catalyst seriously, where a large number of studies have been performed to investigate the effect of the alkali metals on the V-based catalyst. The results showed that the alkali metals inhibit the Brønsted acid sites on the catalyst surface, decrease the reducibility of active V5+ sites and promote the increase of monomeric vanadyl species on the catalyst surface [10–13]. However, there are few studies about the poisoning effect of the alkali metals on the Fe-based SCR catalyst. The density functional theory (DFT) is powerful in revealing the poisoning effect mechanism of alkali metals on NH3-SCR catalyst at the molecular level. Combining experimental and theoretical methods, Zhang et al. [14,15] found that alkali metals strongly inhibit the Brønsted acid on the surface of CeSn/TiO2 or CeZr catalysts. Peng [16] investigated the poisoning effect of the alkali metals on the CeO2-WO3 catalyst through DFT, where the alkali metals only significantly inhibit the Brønsted acid. Besides, tungsten was covered by adjacent oxygen atom because of the alkali metals, preventing the adsorption of NH3 molecule. However, in the experimental and theoretical studies of Wei [17], it was found that on the surface of Mn/TiO2 catalyst, the addition of K inhibited the Lewis acid sites, but on the contrary, improved the acidity of the Brønsted acid sites in SCR reaction. And the adsorption capacity of NOx was increased. Fang [18] investigated the poisoning effect of the alkali metals on the MnxOy/Ni (111) surface. Under the influence of the alkali metals, the Mn-O bond were weakened and the ability of Mn sites to adsorb NH3 decreased. These studies indicate that the poisoning mechanism of alkali metals is quite different for different SCR catalyst. Therefore, it is necessary to study the poisoning mechanism of alkali metals on α-Fe2O3 surface. Our recent study [19] pointed out that the de-NOx performance of pure α-Fe2O3 needs to be enhanced by modification. Nevertheless, it is still necessary to investigate the poisoning mechanism of alkali metals on the pure α-Fe2O3 catalyst, which establish the foundation for further research on poisoning mechanism of the doped α-Fe2O3 catalyst. The Na and K are the main components of alkali metals in fly ash, and numerous poisoning mechanism studies have been carried out around these two elements. Therefore, in this paper, the DFT calculation was employed to study the poisoning effects of sodium (Na) and potassium (K) on the α-Fe2O3 catalyst, where the effects of the alkali metals on the Lewis acid site and Brønsted acid site, the NO, NO2 and O2 adsorption capacity and two key reaction steps of the α-Fe2O3 catalyst are principally studied. The calculation results elucidated the poisoning effect of K and Na on the de-NOx performance of the α-Fe2O3 catalyst at the molecular level. 2 Computational methodology and model The CASTEP module was used in this work to complete all the DFT calculations [20]. The supercell model and the calculation parameters of α-Fe2O3 are the same as those of our previous studies [19]. Therefore, here we only give a brief description. The ultrasoft pseudopotential was applied to describe the ionic core and the electronic wave functions were expanded in a plane wave basis set. The electron exchange correlation energy was described by the functional of Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) at Generalized Gradient Approximation (GGA) level [21,22]. The 2 × 2×1 of K-point was sampled for Brillouin zone integration and the energy cutoff was 400 eV. The GGA + U method was used with U =4.0 eV for the Fe-3d electrons [23]. The X-ray photoelectron diffraction study demonstrated that the (001) facet is a predominant growth face [24]. The Fe-O3-Fe terminated nine atomic layer supercell model (2 × 2) with a vacuum layer of 15 Å was built to simulate the (001) surface of α-Fe2O3, as shown in Fig. 1 [25–28]. The methods of complete LST/QST are used to search the transition states (TS) for reactions [29]. The reaction energy barrier is defined as Eq. (1). (1) ΔE = ETS- EReactant ETS represents the energy of the transition state and EReactant represents the energy of the reactant. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The location of alkali metal on the α-Fe2O3 (001) surface In the industry condition, alkali metals usually exist as metal oxides [30,31]. Gong [32] pointed out that the bond energies of NaO and K–O are 270.0, 271.5 kJ/mol-1, respectively, which is similar to our results of alkali metals adsorption energy below. Considering the influence of the catalyst, we can approximately think that the environment formed between K and surface oxygen is similar to that of potassium oxide. Besides, there are a large number of researches using the same modeling method as in this work, and their calculation results can be well verified by experimental phenomena [17,33–35]. Therefore, the model of this work can be used to investigate the poisoning effects of K2O species. Firstly, the best adsorption sites of alkali metals on the α-Fe2O3 (001) surface are investigated. Three possible adsorption sites (1, 2 and 3-sites) of alkali metals on the Fe2O3 (001) surface and the corresponding optimized adsorption structures of the K atom on the possible sites are presented in Fig. 2 . 1-site is the surface oxygen site, and the other two sites are non-atomic center sites with high symmetry. No matter where the initial adsorption site of K atom is, K atom will finally be stable at the adsorption site similar to 2-site after optimization. Therefore, the adsorption sites similar to 2-site are the best adsorption site for the alkali metals. In addition, for the V2O5 (010) surface, the alkali metals also tended to be strongly adsorbed at the non-atomic hole sites [36], which is similar to the best adsorption sites in this paper. In the subsequent calculations, 2-site is selected as the adsorption site of the alkali metals. Table 1 lists the adsorption energies of the alkali metals on the α-Fe2O3 (001) surface. The calculation results show that there is strong interaction between the alkali metals and α-Fe2O3 (001) surface. In other words, the alkali metals can easily poison the α-Fe2O3 catalyst. In addition, compared with the results calculated by Witko [36], the alkali metals resistance of Fe2O3 (001) surface is better than that of the V2O5(010) surface. The partial density of states (PDOS) is a powerful tool to deeply understand the interaction. The PDOS of different atoms in the fresh and poisoned systems are shown in Fig. 3 . Here, the Fe and O atoms are located at A and B position, respectively, as shown in the Fig. 1. In the following text, all the Fe sites are in the B position. Firstly, both the PDOS (sum of s- and p-orbital) of K and Na shift to the higher energy level after adsorption. However, all the peaks decrease during the moving process. Meanwhile, the peaks in the conduction band have the most obvious reduction, implying that the valence electrons in the K or Na atom move to the surface. Then, by comparison, there is no overlap between the peaks of the O and alkali metals in the whole energy range in the poisoned systems, showing the strong interaction between the alkali metals and α-Fe2O3 (001) surface is produced by the ionic bond. Finally, the effect of alkali metals on the 3d orbital of Fe is analyzed. The results show that the Fe-3d orbital peaks vary lightly in the Na-Fe2O3 system. While, in the K-Fe2O3 system, the d orbital peaks obviously move to the higher energy level, which is more easily to lose electrons. Thus, it is clear that the reactivity of Fe site is influenced by the alkali metals. The specific effects will be discussed in the following section. 3.2 The poisoning effect of the alkali metals on the acid sites of α-Fe2O3 (001) surface The adsorption energy of NH3 at different acid sites can indicate the acid strength. The higher value of the adsorption energy means the stronger level of the acid strength [37,38]. It is well known that the adsorption and activation of the NH3 on the Lewis acid sites are the momentous steps in the NH3-SCR reaction [39,40]. In addition, the NH4+ species adsorbed on the Brønsted acid sites are important in the low temperature region for the NH3-SCR reaction [41]. Thus, we evaluate the poisoning effect of the alkali metals on the surface acid sites of the α-Fe2O3 catalyst through the NH3 adsorption. Figs. 4 and 5 depicts the optimized adsorption configuration of the NH3 molecule on the Lewis acid sites and the Brønsted acid sites of K/Na-Fe2O3 (001) surface. Meanwhile, the partial structure and adsorption energy data are shown in Table 2 . The N-Fe represents the distance between the N atom of the NH3 molecule and the Fe atom, and the N-H represents the distance between the N atom and the H atom of the Brønsted acid sites. According to our previous data [19], the adsorption energy of NH3 on the Lewis site of the fresh Fe2O3 is 1.22 eV and the bond length of NFe is 2.14 Å. The data in Table 2 show that no distinct variations are observed in the adsorption energies of NH3 and the bond length of N-Fe in the K/Na-Fe2O3 systems. These results show that the strength of the Lewis acid sites on the α-Fe2O3 (001) surface is not affected by the poisoning of K or Na. Compared to the N-H distance (1.69 Å) in the fresh Fe2O3 catalyst, the distance for the Na and K-Fe2O3 catalyst are calculated to be 2.86 and 2.98 Å, respectively. The larger distances indicate that in the alkali metals poisoned catalyst, the NH3 molecules do not approach and interact with the Brønsted acid sites around the alkali metals. In other words, the strength of the Brønsted acid sites on the K/Na-Fe2O3 (001) surface is significantly decreased, resulting in the reduction of the de-NOx efficiency of the α-Fe2O3 catalyst. Zhu [42] studied the poisoning effect of K and Na on α-Fe2O3 doped with Mn catalyst by experimental method. They found that K and Na inhibit the Brønsted acid sites and the K element have stronger poisoning effect through the analysis of the de-NOx activity curve. Other experimental studies also proved that the dominated poisoning effect of alkali metals is the deactivation of Brønsted acid site [43,44]. It can be concluded from the above results that alkali metals can not only easily occupy the Brønsted acid sites through proton exchange, but also block the Brønsted acid sites by the method of this work. However, previous research showed that the number of Lewis-acid sites were greatly larger than that of Brønsted acid sites on the surface of α-Fe2O3 [45]. Therefore, although alkali metals strongly inhibit the Brønsted acid sites, the deactivation of Brønsted acid sites is not the main reason for decreasing the de-NOx performance of the α-Fe2O3 catalyst. Interestingly, although NH3 do not interact with Brønsted acid sites, the Ead of NH3 on K or Na poisoned surface are slightly higher than that on the fresh surface. It can be seen from Fig. 5 that the NH3 molecules face the alkali metals instead of the Brønsted acid sites after adsorption. Therefore, the abnormal increase of adsorption energy may be attributed to alkali metals and the hydrogen bond between NH3 and the surface oxygen. In order to further confirm the above inference, the electronic structures of many atoms in Fe2O3, Na-Fe2O3 and K-Fe2O3 systems are calculated, as shown in Figs. 6 and 7 . From the picture (a) of the Fig. 6, we can observe that whether in alkali metals poisoned system or no poisoned system, all the peaks of N decrease and move to lower energy level after adsorption. And the shift distance and the decrease degree of peaks are almost the same. From the picture (b) of the Fig. 5, after the NH3 adsorbed on the Lewis acid sites, the electronic structures of Fe-3d orbital differ little among the three systems. From the above results, we can infer indicate that the strength of the Lewis acid site isn't affected by the alkali metals. By observing the picture (a) in Fig. 7, All the peaks of the FeOH (the Brønsted acid site) present no variation after adsorption, indicating that the NH3 molecule don't interact with the Brønsted acid site. From the picture (b) of the Fig. 7, we can find that the peaks of N atom shrift left due to electron loss. And the peaks of the alkali metals slightly shift to the higher energy state in the valence region because of receiving electrons and the peaks within the conduction region of the alkali metals also show change. These results show that the alkali metals play a role in the abnormal increase of NH3 adsorption energy. 3.3 Effect of alkali metals on the adsorption capacity of α-Fe2O3 catalyst for NO, NO2 and O2 The previous DFT studies have shown that the NO and NO2 molecules tend to be adsorbed at the Fe site on the Fe2O3 (001) surface with the N-terminal [46], which may have competitive adsorption with NH3. In addition, a large number of the mechanism studies show that the NO adsorbed on the catalyst surface is difficult to react with the free NH3, which thus hinders the NH3-SCR reaction process. While the adsorbed NO2 can easily react with the free NH3 and NH4+, promoting the ‘Fast-SCR’ reaction process [47–49]. Thus, it is essential to investigate the NOx adsorption. The optimized configurations of the NOx (NO and NO2) adsorbed on the Na/K-Fe2O3 (001) surface are shown in the Fig. 8 . Correspondingly, the optimized geometries and adsorption energies of NOx in the Fe2O3, Na-Fe2O3 and K-Fe2O3 system are listed in Table 3 . The adsorption energy of NO on the fresh α-Fe2O3 (001) surface is 0.541 eV, which is obviously smaller than that of NH3 (1.216 eV) at the Lewis acid site of the fresh α-Fe2O3 (001) surface. In other words, it is unable to form competitive adsorption with the NH3. The Ead-NO for Na and K-Fe2O3 systems are calculated to be 0.741 and 1.656 eV, respectively. Obviously, both the Na and K enhance the NO adsorption capacity of the α-Fe2O3 catalyst. And the promoting effect of K is stronger than that of Na. In the K-Fe2O3 system, NO can form competitive adsorption with NH3 and hinder NH3-SCR reaction. The data in Table 3 also show that the NO2 adsorption capacity of the α-Fe2O3 catalyst is also enhanced, and the Ead-NO2 for Na and K-Fe2O3 systems are calculated to be the same (2.09 eV). Compared with NH3 and NO, NO2 has a larger adsorption energy on the Na/K-Fe2O3 (001) surface and will preferentially adsorb and occupy Fe sites. The preferential adsorption of NO2 will promote the ‘Fast-SCR’ reaction. Therefore, it is difficult to infer the change of overall de-NOx efficiency from the change of the adsorption energies of NO and NO2. To solve this problem, we studied the adsorption capacity of O2 in the alkali metals poisoned systems. The optimized adsorption configuration of the O2 molecules on the Fe sites of the Na/K-Fe2O3 systems are shown in Fig. 9 . In the Na/K-Fe2O3 systems, O2 molecules don't interact with the Fe site either in parallel or vertical direction. The adsorption of O2 on the catalyst surface is very important for the conversion of NO to NO2 [50,51]. Therefore, NO can't be converted to NO2 on the surface of Na/K-Fe2O3. From the above results, we can infer that if the fraction of NO2 in the flue gas is less, the de-NOx efficiency of the catalyst will undoubtedly decrease. 3.4 Effect of alkali metals on key steps in NH3-SCR reaction A great quantity of studies had shown that the NH3 dehydrogenation is an important initial step [52]. For many catalysts [40,53], including α-Fe2O3 [54], the formation and desorption of H2O are the rate determining steps of NH3-SCR. Therefore, we study the influence of alkali metals on these key reactions. The Fig. 10 shows the potential energy diagram of the reaction of (a) NH3 dehydrogenation and (b) formation of H2O. The Fig. 11 presents the optimized structures of each state of two key reactions in the K-Fe2O3 system (The structures for each state of two key reactions are similar in all systems, so only the structures in K-Fe2O3 system are shown). The energy barriers of the NH3 dehydrogenation are calculated to be 1.53, 1.48 and 1.65 eV for Fe2O3, Na-Fe2O3 and K-Fe2O3 systems, respectively. These energy barriers have little difference. Thus, we can infer that the alkali metals can't affect the reaction of NH3 dehydrogenation. Meanwhile, this also verify the Fe sites (Lewis acid site) don't affect by the alkali metals. The order for energy barriers of the formation of H2O follow the sequence: Fe2O3(1.18 eV) ＜ Na-Fe2O3(1.59 eV)＜K-Fe2O3(1.98 eV). We can find that the formation of H2O is more difficult in alkali metals poisoned systems, and thus the NH3-SCR reaction is inhibited. Otherwise, our results show that H2O is very easy to decompose on the Fe2O3 (001) surface with the presence of alkali metals, which was also found in previous studies [35]. 4 Conclusions The DFT method is employed to research the poisoning effect of the alkali metals (K and Na) on the α-Fe2O3 catalyst in the NH3-SCR, where the effects of the alkali metals on the Lewis acid site, the Brønsted acid site, the NOx and O2 adsorption capacity and two key reactions of the α-Fe2O3 catalyst are principally studied. The important results are summarized as follows: Compared with the Na atom, the K atom is more strongly adsorbed on the α-Fe2O3 (001) surface with the adsorption energy of 3.72 eV. After the addition of K and Na, the strength of Lewis acid sites on the surface are not affected, while the strength of Brønsted acid sites is significantly decreased, which thus decreases the de-NOx efficiency of the α-Fe2O3 catalyst. Both the K and Na atom can enhance the NO and NO2 adsorption capacity of the α-Fe2O3 catalyst and the promoting effect of K is stronger. The adsorption energy of NO (1.656 eV) in the K-Fe2O3 system is significantly higher than that of NH3 (1.149 eV), which causes the competitive adsorption with NH3 to deactivate the α-Fe2O3 catalyst. In addition, the O2 adsorption capacity of the α-Fe2O3 catalyst is inhibited, which hinder the conversion of NO to NO2. The reduction of the adsorbed NO2 indicates the ‘Fast SCR’ pathway is inhibited. In the K or Na-Fe2O3 systems, the reaction of NH3 dehydrogenation isn't affected. However, the formation of H2O is strongly restrained, which is another reason for the decrease of de-NOx efficiency. coredata.dc:description: The poisoning effect of potassium (K) and sodium (Na) on the α-Fe2O3 catalyst in the ammonia-selective catalytic reduction (NH3-SCR) for the NO reduction was investigated by the density functional theory calculation. The results show that, in the presence of alkali metals, the strength of the Lewis acid site on the surface is not affected, while the strength of the Brønsted acid site is significantly inhibited, which thus decreases the de-NOx performance of the α-Fe2O3 catalyst. Both K and Na enhance the NOx (NO and NO2) adsorption capacity and inhibit the O2 adsorption capacity of the α-Fe2O3 catalyst. These data indicate that NO and NH3 form competitive adsorption, and the ‘Fast-SCR’ reaction is inhibited in the alkali metal poisoned systems. In addition, the alkali metals don't affect the dehydrogenation of NH3, but inhibit the formation of H2O which is the rate determination step of NH3-SCR for α-Fe2O3 catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Theoretical insights into the poisoning effect of Na and K on α-Fe2O3 catalyst for selective catalytic reduction of NO with NH3
